summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. It provides notice and description of anticipated testimony from an FBI CART forensic examiner regarding the cloning and analysis of electronic devices (Government Exhibits 54 and 55) and related metadata, which includes files saved under a user profile named 'GMax'.

persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) to which this government letter pertains. Files on the examined devices were saved under a user profile named 'GMax'.

persons.name: Damian Williams

events.title: Government's Prior Expert Notice
events.description: The Government previously provided notice regarding anticipated expert testimony, referencing an FBI CART examiner's curriculum vitae.

events.title: Forensic Examination of Maxwell's Devices
events.description: An FBI CART examiner forensically imaged and analyzed devices marked as Government Exhibits 54 and 55, identifying files and metadata associated with a user profile 'GMax'.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, 800 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East Tenth Avenue, Denver, CO 80203
Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim, 33 West 19th Street-4th Fl., New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The government plans to offer testimony from an FBI Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) forensic examiner regarding cloned electronic devices (Gov't Ex. 54 & 55).
Files on Government Exhibit 54, including Word documents (Gov't Ex. 418, 420, 421, 422), were saved under a user profile named 'GMax', directly linking them to Ghislaine Maxwell.
The examiner will testify that hash values confirm the forensic images are exact copies of the original devices, ensuring evidence integrity.

The document is a formal notice to defense counsel (Everdell, Menninger, Pagliuca, Stemheim) about the scope of anticipated forensic testimony, arguing it is factual observation, not expert opinion requiring Rule 702.
The letter references the examiner's prior testimony in other federal cases (United States v. Hirst, DiTomasso, Healey) to establish the routine nature of the described forensic processes.
